DOC.HEAD: Russian Orthodox Priests Join the Ukrainian Catholic Church
DOC.TEXT: Ukrainian Catholic Church officials said Tuesday that at least 100 Russian Orthodox priests and 200 parishes in the Ukraine have registered as Catholics since the Ukrainian government first recognized the church Dec. 1. The Ukrainian church officials, based in Rome, said the orthodox parishes that shifted to Catholicism are near Lvov, in the Western Ukraine. The officials said figures for the rest of the Ukraine are not yet available. According to Western estimates, there are 4 to 6 million Catholics in the Ukraine. Soviet leader Josef Stalin suppressed their church in 1946, forcing them to convert to Russian Orthodox or to practice their religion clandestinely. However, on Dec. 1, Ukrainian authorities announced they would allow Catholic congregations to register like other groups. Rome-based Cardinal Myroslav Lubachivsky called it a ``first step'' toward complete legalization. The Russian Orthodox have opposed legalization of the Ukrainian Catholic Church, as they stand to lose hundreds of churches and thousands of followers they gained after the 1946 repression. The decision to allow Catholic congregations to register was announced as Pope John Paul II held talks with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at the Vatican, where the pope appealed to Gorbachev to assure full religious freedom for Catholics in the Soviet Union.
